The terminal is a text-based interface that allows you to interact directly with your computer/operating system by typing commands.
Alternative names:
â€œterminalâ€, â€œcommand lineâ€, â€œshellâ€, â€œcommand promptâ€
Some terminology:

Shell: the program that interprets your commands (e.g.Â bash, zsh, PowerShell)


You donâ€™t need to worry about the difference at the beginning.

Almost everything you can do with a graphical interface can also be done from the terminal.
The terminal is often:

more precise and reproducible
easier to automate
available on almost every system

Because of this, terminals are widely used in programming, data science, and research workflows.

Compared to a basic text editor, an IDE typically provides:

syntax highlighting
code completion and suggestions
error detection
integrated terminal
debugging tools

Examples: VSCode, Pycharm, RStudio, Posit

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
Manual Command
On Linux and Mac, the man command is used to show the manual of any command that you can run in the terminal. So if you wanted to know more about the ls command, you could run:
  man ls
Unfortunately, if you are on Windows and using Git Bash, the man command is not included, however, you can just type the command that you want to know more about and then --help and you will get similar info:
  ls --help
You should be able to use the arrow keys or page up and down. When you are ready to exit, just press q.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
File System Navigation
Commands to navigate your file system are very important. You will be using them all the time. You wonâ€™t remember every single command that you use, but these are the ones that you should remember.







Command
Description




pwd
Stands for print working directory, and as the name suggests, it is used to print out the absolute path to the current directory.


ls (dir in Windows)
Lists files and directories under a specific path, or the current working directory whenever a path is not provided.


ls -a
List contents including hidden files (Files that begin with a dot)


ls -l
List contents with more info including permissions (long listing)


ls -r
List contents reverse order


cd 
The cd command is used to change the current working directory and navigate across the file directory of the host machine.


cd [dirname]
Change directory to specific directory


cd ~
Change to home directory


cd ..
Change to parent directory


cd -
Change to previous directory (which could be different than the parent of course)


find [dirtosearch] -name [filename]
Find location of a program



Note for Windows users: The ls commands above work in Unix/macOS terminals. On Windows, the commands differ depending on your terminal:
PowerShell: ls is an alias for Get-ChildItem, so the equivalent commands are: - ls -a â†’ ls -Force or Get-ChildItem -Force (to show hidden files) - ls -l â†’ ls | Format-List or Get-ChildItem | Format-List (for detailed listing) - ls -r â†’ ls | Sort-Object Name -Descending
Command Prompt (cmd): Use dir instead of ls: - ls â†’ dir (list files and directories) - ls -a â†’ dir /a (show hidden files) - ls -l â†’ dir (already shows detailed info by default)
Of course, you can group flags together. For example, if I want to see more info and view hidden files, I could do ls -l -a and even shorten it to ls -la.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The cat (concatenate) Command
The cat command is a very common command and allows you to create single or multiple files, view content of a file, concatenate files and redirect output in terminal or files.
The most common thing I use it for is to display the contents of a file:
  cat [filename]
You can also view the contents of multiple files:
  cat [filename] [filename]
You can also create a file using the cat command:
  cat > [filename]
This will open up a new file and you can start typing. When you are done, you can press Ctrl + D to save and exit.
You can also append to a file:
  cat >> [filename]
This will open up the file and you can start typing. When you are done, you can press Ctrl + D to save and exit.
You can use it to show line numbers:
  cat -n [filename]
There are other uses as well, but as you can see, the cat command is very powerful.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The less Command
The less command is used to view the contents of a file. It is similar to the cat command, but it allows you to scroll up and down.
  less [filename]
To exit the less command, just press q.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The echo Command
The echo command is used to display messages, or to create and write to files. It is similar to the cat command, but it is used to display a single line of text.
  echo "Hello World"
You can also use it to create a file:
  echo "Hello World" > [filename]
You can also append to a file:
  echo "Hello World" >> [filename]

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The nano Command
The nano command is a text editor that is installed by default on most Linux distributions, MacOS and you can even use it with Git Bash on Windows. It is very similar to the vim editor, but it is much easier to use.
You can open an existing file to edit or create a new file and open it with:
  nano [filename]
When youâ€™re ready to exit, just hit Ctrl + X and then Y to save and N to not save.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The head and tail Commands
The head command is used to output the first part of files. By default, it outputs the first 10 lines of each file. You can also specify the number of lines to output.
  head [filename]
You can also specify the number of lines to output:
  head -n 5 [filename]
The tail command is used to output the last part of files. By default, it outputs the last 10 lines of each file. You can also specify the number of lines to output.
  tail [filename]
You can also specify the number of lines to output:
  tail -n 5 [filename]

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The grep Command
The grep command is used to search for a text pattern in a file. It is very powerful and can be used to search for a string or regular expression in a file or set of files.
  grep [searchterm] [filename]
You can also search for a string in multiple files:
  grep [searchterm] [filename] [filename]
There are a lot more things that you can do with the grep command, but itâ€™s a but more advanced.

title: Common Terminal Commands
text:
The find command
The find command is extremely powerful and is used to find the location of files and directories based on conditions that you specify.
To start off by creating something to work with. Letâ€™s create 100 files in the current directory. This is one of those things that I talked about earlier where you can do certain things much faster than you could in the GUI. We already know that the touch command will create a file. It can also be used to create multiple files.
  touch file-{001..100}.txt

After your first push, do nothing for a moment. Something changes on GitHub (your colleague pushed a change). GitHub will automatically add a new line to exercise.txt. In this simulated situation, your local files are unchanged but the the remote repository is ahead.


Local commits vs remote commits
We are in the situation where you have already pushed once and the remote repo has changed. Imagine you forgot to pull the remote and you are working ahead on your local directory.
Open exercise.txt again. Add a new line at the end, for example: â€œI made another local change before pulling.â€ Save the file and commit. Do not push yet.
Solution:
git status
git add exercise.txt
git commit -m "Add another local change"
At this point, you are ahead locally and the remote is also ahead. The histories have â€œdivergedâ€.
Now pull the changes to your computer, then open exercise.txt again. Check the changes using git status. Notice the new commits in your GUI.
Solution:
git pull
Your local changes are not erased: Git combines your local commit and the remote commit. The file now contains both changes.
Check the history in your GUI.
git log --oneline
As a final step, push the combined history back to GitHub.

Key takeaway
If the remote is ahead, and you commit locally, and you then pull, Git does not delete your work, but tries to combine the histories automatically.
